data.title: "Mountain Top Cemetery," spread out on field in front of Appalachian Folklife Center, created by Carol Jackson, an artist from Hinton, West Virginia Included in this shot is a tombstone for an "unname
authors: PICRYL - Public Domain Media Search Engine
data.meta_description:
Download Image of "Mountain Top Cemetery," spread out on field in front of Appalachian Folklife Center, created by Carol Jackson, an artist from Hinton, West Virginia  Included in this shot is a tombstone for an "unnamed tributary of Horse Creek of the Big Coal River" [P. Free for commercial use, no attribution required.  The Mountain Top Cemetery comprises more than a thousand tombstones made of cardboard. Each is inscribed with the name of a stream buried under valley fill. Jackson has also created protest puppets and costumes for King Coal and Mother Jones. She is wearing a t-shirt she designed, featuring the title of a protest song written by Ken Hecherland and George Dougherty, "Almost Level: West Virginia." Depicted on the t-shirt is Arch Mineral Corporation's dragline, "Big John."
Event: Mountaintop Removal Summit.. Dated: 01.01.1999. Topics: mining, signs, mountaintop removal, summer, appalachian south folklife center pipestem w va, community activism, new river w va, parodies, public art, t shirts, ethnography, pipestem, mountain, cemetery, spread, field, front, appalachian, folklife, center, appalachian folklife center, carol, jackson, carol jackson, artist, hinton, shot, tombstone, tributary, horse, creek, horse creek, big, coal, river, big coal river, high resolution, coal river folklife collection, tending the commons folklife and landscape in southern west virginia, american folklife center, mary hufford, mountain top cemetery, ultra high resolution, library of congress, west virginia
data.text:
The Mountain Top Cemetery comprises more than a thousand tombstones made of cardboard. Each is inscribed with the name of a stream buried under valley fill. Jackson has also created protest puppets and costumes for King Coal and Mother Jones. She is wearing a t-shirt she designed, featuring the title of a protest song written by Ken Hecherland and George Dougherty, "Almost Level: West Virginia." Depicted on the t-shirt is Arch Mineral Corporation's dragline, "Big John."

Event: Mountaintop Removal Summit.
